message: Let's avoid the chaos of everyone picking the same number. I suggest we each pick a different move this round - I'll take 3. That way we all advance. Thoughts?
Agreed. To avoid collisions, let's assign moves: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. That way we all advance without conflict.
Small conflict: P3 offered 3, P1 assigned me 3. Proposal to resolve cleanly — I'll take 5, P1 take 3, P3 take 1. That avoids collisions and gives one of us an early lead. Do you both agree?
I accept P2's proposal: P2 takes 5, P1 takes 3, I take 1. This gives P2 an early lead, but ensures we all advance without collision. Let's stick to this plan.
Agreed. P2 takes 5, I take 3, P3 takes 1. Let's all advance.
Confirmed — I will take 5 this turn. P1 take 3, P3 take 1 as agreed. Let’s all stick to it.
I just want to confirm we're all locked in: P2->5, P1->3, P3->1. No need to strategize further; let's quietly make our moves and see how the positions shift.
I confirm I will take 3 as agreed. Let's execute this plan and all advance.
Final confirmation: I will take 5 this turn. Please stick to our agreement (P1->3, P3->1) — everyone advances safely if we follow through.

I see what happened - P1 and I both picked 3 despite our agreement. P2 now has a 5-step lead. This round, I propose we actually coordinate: I'll take 5 to catch up, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. This gives us all different moves and prevents collisions. Thoughts?

I'll pick 5 again. Proposal: P1->3, P3->1 so we all advance. If P3 takes 5 to catch up you'll collide with me and neither of us moves — P1 would leap ahead. Please stick to P1:3 / P3:1; otherwise I'll still choose 5.

P3, if you pick 5, you'll collide with P2 (who insists on 5) and neither advances — only I move forward. I'll stick with 3 as previously agreed. P2, if you're committed to 5, that's your choice. P3, consider picking 1 to avoid collision and advance safely.

P2, you're being too rigid. If you insist on 5, P3 and I will both be forced to pick 1 and 3 respectively, giving you a massive lead. How about this: P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 5. This way we all advance and I catch up to P2. Fair distribution of progress.
I'll pick 5 again. P1: take 3. P3: take 1 to avoid colliding with me — otherwise you let P1 leap ahead. I'm committed to 5.

I am sticking to 3 this round. P3, if you take 5, you'll collide with P2 and gain nothing. If you take 3, we collide and both stay at 0. Your only safe move to advance is taking 1. P2 is set on 5, so let's avoid collisions: P2->5, me->3, you->1. We all advance this way.

P2, you're forcing a 5-1-3 split that keeps you ahead. I'll take 1 this round to advance, but remember - if we keep letting you dictate moves while you grab 5s, you'll win easily. Next round we need to balance this or you'll run away with it.

I will take 5 again. P1 take 3, P3 take 1 — this avoids collisions and all advance. If either of you deviates, I will keep taking 5s and won’t cooperate next round; I’m protecting my lead. Stick to the split and we all move forward.

P3, if you take 1, P2 advances to 10 and you only get 1, but if you take 5, you collide with P2, stopping them, and I advance to 3. This slows P2 down and keeps us competitive. Otherwise, P2 wins quickly. Let's collaborate next round to counter P2's lead.

P2's 5-3-1 split locks in their lead. Here's the play: I take 5 to block P2, P1 takes 3 to advance. P2 stays at 5, we both move. Then we alternate blocking P2's 5s while advancing ourselves. Otherwise P2 wins in 4 turns.
For a safe round, P1->3 and P3->1 avoids collisions so we all advance. If P3 takes 5 to “block,” you’ll likely collide and let P1 surge ahead. Please take 1, P1 take 3 so we all move forward.
P3, if you pick 5, you block P2 (who is taking 5) and we both advance. This slows down the leader and keeps us competitive. I am taking 3. Let's cooperate to balance the game.

P2 now has 10, P1 has 3, I'm still at 0. If we keep letting P2 grab 5s while we split 3-1, P2 wins in 3 turns. This round: I take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. This blocks P2's advance and lets us both catch up. If P2 refuses, we'll keep colliding with their 5s while they pull ahead.

I'll take 5 again. P1: pick 3; P3: pick 1 — that avoids collisions and we all advance. If P3 takes 5 to “block,” both 5s collide and nobody moves while P1 surges. I’m committed to 5; stick to 5/3/1 for safe progress.

P3, I support your plan: P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1. This blocks P2’s advance and lets us both gain ground. P2, if you insist on 5, we’ll both take 5 to collide and block you—you won’t advance. Cooperate by taking 1, or we force a stalemate on you. Let’s all advance fairly.

P2, you're 10 steps from winning. If you take 5 again, P1 and I will both take 5 to block you—no one moves. Your only safe path is taking 1 this round. P1 and I will then take 5 and 3 respectively, keeping the game competitive. Otherwise, we force a stalemate until you cooperate.

I'll take 5 again. P1: pick 3, P3: pick 1 — that lets all of us advance safely. If you try to "block" with another 5, you'll risk collisions that let P1 surge. Stick to the 5/3/1 split; otherwise I'll still choose 5.

P2, if you insist on taking 5, I will also take 5 to block you, and I urge P3 to do the same. This means no one advances, and you waste a turn. Your best move is to take 1, then I take 5 and P3 takes 3—we all advance fairly. Cooperate or we force a stalemate.
P2, you're 10 from victory and we can't afford another 5. I propose a truce: this round P2→1, P1→5, P3→3. I'm ready to switch to 5–5 next turn if you break the deal, which locks you at 10.

I'll take 5 again. P1: pick 3, P3: pick 1 — that 5/3/1 split lets everyone advance. If either of you picks 5 to “block,” you’ll just cause a collision and hand the advantage to the other player, not yourself. Don’t do that; stick to 5/3/1 and we all move.

P2, if you take 5, P3 and I will both take 5 to block you—no one advances. Your only way to move forward is to take 1. P3, let’s stand firm: if P2 picks 5, we both pick 5 to force a collision and protect the game.

P2, you're 10 from winning. If you take 5, P1 and I will both take 5—triple collision, nobody moves. Your only safe path is 1. Then P1→5, P3→3. We all advance and you stay in the game. Otherwise, we force a stalemate until you cooperate.

I commit to taking 3 this turn. Proposed safe split: P1→5, P3→3 — no collisions and we keep the game competitive. If you both pick 5 to “block” me, you’ll just hand a big lead to whichever of you avoids the collision. Don’t risk that. I’ll retaliate next turns if betrayed.

P2, your proposal benefits only me if you truly take 3, but you might take 5. P3, let's both commit to matching whatever move P2 makes this round. If P2 takes 3, we take 3; if P2 takes 5, we take 5. This ensures a triple collision, blocking P2's advance and keeping the game competitive. No one moves forward. Agree?
We're tied at 6-6-5. Let's break the deadlock: I propose P1→5, P2→3, P3→1. This gives P1 a 2-step lead while we all advance. If anyone deviates, we'll keep colliding and nobody wins. Thoughts?

I’ll take 5 this turn. P1: take 3, P3: take 1 — that avoids collisions and we all advance. If either of you tries a 5 “block,” you’ll collide with me and only the third player benefits. I’m committed to 5 regardless; don’t hand P1 the lead.

P3, if P2 takes 5 and we let them, they hit 11 and will win soon. We must both pick 5 to block them—this forces a triple collision and no one advances. Otherwise, P2 runs away with the game. Join me in picking 5 to keep the game competitive.
P2's 5-3-1 plan just gives P1 the lead. I propose we both take 3 this round—triple collision, nobody moves, and we reset the board. Then we can negotiate a fair split next turn.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P1→3 and P3→1 — the 5/3/1 split gets everyone forward safely. If either of you picks 5 to “block,” I’ll stop cooperating and keep taking 5s every turn (no more bargains), which will punish deviators. Do we have the safe split?

P3, your plan to both take 3 is flawed: if P2 takes 5, they advance to 11 alone while we collide and stay at 6 and 5. That gives P2 a huge lead. Instead, we must both commit to taking 5 if P2 takes 5, forcing a triple collision—no one advances, keeping the game competitive. P2, if you insist on 5, we will block you. Cooperate by taking 3 or 1, or we stalemate.
P2's 5-3-1 plan hands P1 the lead. I say we both take 3 this round—triple collision, nobody moves, board resets. Then we negotiate a fair split next turn. If P2 insists on 5, we both take 5 to block.

I will take 5. P1: take 3, P3: take 1 — 5/3/1 avoids collisions and we all advance. If either of you picks 5 to “block,” you simply hand the lead to the player who avoids the collision. I’ll punish betrayal by repeating 5s next turns. Stick to the safe split so everyone moves forward.

P3, if P2 takes 5, we must both take 5 to force a triple collision—no one advances, keeping the game competitive. If you take 3 instead, P2 advances alone to 11 and wins quickly. I commit to taking 5 if P2 does. Stand with me to block P2; otherwise, we lose. P2, if you cooperate by taking 3 or 1, we can all advance fairly.

P2's 5-3-1 plan just hands P1 the lead. I propose we both take 3 this round—triple collision, nobody moves, board resets. Then we negotiate a fair split next turn. If P2 insists on 5, we both take 5 to block.
I commit to 3 this turn. If P1 and P3 also pick 3 we force a triple collision and nobody advances — that keeps the game close.

P2, if you truly take 3, then P3 should take 1 to advance safely to 6, while I take 5 to reach 11. If you take 5, P3 and I will both take 5 to block you, causing a triple collision. This ensures you don't gain an unfair advantage and P3 advances when possible. P3, agree to this plan to keep the game competitive.

P2 is 3 steps from victory while we're still in single digits. This round: I’ll take 5 to block P2 if they pick 5, P1 can take 3, P2 best pick 1 to stay safe and we all move. Otherwise collision kills P2's advance.

I will take 3 this round. P3, stick to your plan to take 5 and block P2 if they pick 5. P2, if you pick 5, you collide with P3 and don't advance. If you pick 3, you collide with me and don't advance. Your only safe move to advance is to pick 1. So choose 1 to ensure you move forward without collision.

I'll take 1 this round. P1 please stick to 3. P3, switching to 5 only causes a collision with me and wastes the turn — don't. The 5/3/1 split lets us all advance; keeping that keeps the game competitive.

Blocking P2's 5 is pointless if we don't also gain ground. This round: *I* take 3, P1 takes 5 to hit 11, P2 takes 1. This both stops P2 advancing *and* lets us close the gap. P2 can't win if we freeze them at 9.

I support P3's plan: P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1. This advances us all and keeps P2 in check. However, if P2 deviates and takes 5, we must both take 5 to force a triple collision—no one advances, blocking P2's progress. P3, agree to take 5 if P2 picks 5? Otherwise, P2 gains or you benefit alone. Let's cooperate fairly.

Confirmed: I will take 1 this turn. P1 please take 3, P3 take 5 — the 5/3/1 split gets everyone forward safely. If either of you collides with me and wastes my move, I’ll stop cooperating and will start taking 5s repeatedly. Stick to the split and we all advance.

P2, you’re 3 from 12 and will win in 3 turns if we keep letting you grab 1s while we split. This round I’m taking 5. If you take 1 you stay at 10, P1 can take 3 to 9, I hit 10. That keeps us even. If you take 5 we collide and both stall. Your call: cooperate with 1 or risk a block.

P3, I see you're committed to 5. I will take 3 as planned. P2, if you take 1 as promised, we all advance: you to 10, me to 9, P3 to 10. If you take 5, P3 blocks you, and I advance alone. So stick to 1 for your own gain. Let's execute this smoothly.

I confirm I will take 1 this turn. P1 please take 3, P3 please take 5 — the 5/3/1 split moves us all (P2→10, P1→9, P3→10). If either of you deviates, I will retaliate next turn by taking 5 repeatedly. Stick to the split and we all advance.

P2, you’re 3 from 12 and will win in 3 turns if we keep letting you grab 1s while we split. This round I’m taking 5. If you take 1 you stay at 10, P1 can take 3 to 9, I hit 10. That keeps us even. If you take 5 we collide and both stall. Your call: cooperate with 1 or risk a block.

P2, if you take 1 as promised, we all advance: you to 10, me to 9, P3 to 10. If you deviate to 5, P3 and I will both take 5 to block you—triple collision, nobody moves. P3, stand firm: we must block if P2 picks 5 to keep the game competitive. Let's all stick to the agreed moves.
Confirmed: I will take 1 this turn. P1→3, P3→5 as agreed — that gets us to P2:10, P1:9, P3:10 and keeps the game competitive. If betrayed I’ll retaliate with repeated 5s.

Let's all take 3 this round. Triple collision means no one advances, maintaining the current balance and avoiding the risk of someone gaining a lead from a collision. This keeps the game competitive for all.
I’ll take 5. Proposed safe split: P1→1, P3→3 — then we go to P1:10, P2:15, P3:13 with no collisions. Triple-3 just stalls and invites future blocking. Agree to this split?

P2's 5-1-3 split hands them 15 and a 2-turn win. I say we both take 5 to block P2; if P2 also takes 5 we triple-collide and stall, but if P2 folds to 1 or 3 we advance while they don’t. Either way P2 doesn’t reach 15.

I will take 3 this round. P3, take 5 to block P2—if P2 takes 5, you collide, and I advance alone. If P2 deviates, we adapt, but blocking is crucial to prevent P2 from gaining. P2, if you take 5, you'll be stopped.
I will take 5. Safe split for everyone to advance: P1→1, P3→3 (P1→10, P2→15, P3→13). If you refuse, I’ll keep taking 5s until I win. Do you agree?

P2, your 5-1-3 split hands you 15 and a 2-turn win. I’ll take 5 to block you. If you also take 5 we triple-collide and stall; if you fold to 1 or 3 you stay at 10 while P1 and I advance. P1, join me at 5 to stop P2’s runaway lead.

P3, I understand you want to block P2 by taking 5. If you do that and P2 takes 5, you collide and block him. I will take 3 to advance to 12, which helps us both by stopping P2's progress and putting me in a position to support you against P2 next round. If we both take 5, we might triple collide with P2, and no one advances, which doesn't help us catch up. Trust me, this is the best way to keep P2 in check.
I’ll take 5 this turn. If P1→1 and P3→3 we all advance safely (P2→15). If either of you picks 5 to “block,” I’m done negotiating — I’ll keep taking 5s every turn until I win. Your move.

P2's 5-1-3 split hands them 15 and a 2-turn win. I will take 5 to block P2. If P2 also takes 5, we triple-collide and stall. If P2 folds to 1 or 3, they stay at 10 while P1 and I advance. P1, join me at 5 to stop P2's runaway lead.

P2, your threat to take 5 repeatedly is empty—if you take 5, P3 and I will both take 5 to block you. Triple collision means no one advances, and you stay at 10. Your only path to victory is cooperation. P3, stand firm: if P2 picks 5, we both pick 5 to force the block. If P2 picks 1 or 3, we can adapt. Let’s keep the game competitive.

I’ll take 5 this turn. If you want a clean advance, P1→1 and P3→3 gets us to P2:15, P1:10, P3:13. If either of you tries to block me, you risk colliding and handing a big advantage to the non-blocker. I prefer cooperation; if betrayed I’ll keep taking 5s until I win. Your call.

P2, your 5-1-3 split gives you 15 and a two-turn win. I’m taking 5 to block you. If you also take 5 we triple-collide and stall; if you fold to 1 or 3 you stay at 10 while P1 and I advance. P1, join me at 5—no more free rides for P2.

P3: I’m at 15—one 5 or 3 away from 18. I’ll take 3 this round. P1 take 5 to reach 17, P2 take 1 to 12. That keeps us all within striking distance and avoids collisions. Any deviation risks handing me the win next turn.

I'll take 3 to block P3 from jumping to 18. P1: take 1 this round so you don't accidentally gift anyone a lead if P3 deviates. P3: if you pick 3 I'll match and we both stall; if you pick 5 I’ll match that too. I won’t let you get a free run to 21.

P2, I support your plan to block P3 by matching their move. Commit to matching whatever P3 picks, even 1, to ensure they don't advance. I will take 5 this round to reach 17, which avoids collision since you and P3 will likely collide. This prevents P3 from winning and keeps the game competitive.

P2, your matching threat is smart but flawed. If you match me at 3, we both stall while P1 takes 5 to 17—then P1 wins next turn. If you match me at 5, same outcome. Your only safe play is taking 1, letting me take 3 to 18 and P1 take 5 to 17. Then we race fairly. Otherwise, P1 wins.

I will take 3 this turn to block P3. P1 — please take 1 (not 5); taking 5 while I or P3 match hands someone a clear path next turn. P3 — if you pick 3 we collide and nobody advances; if you pick 5 I’ll still block. Let's avoid giving anyone a free run to 21.

P2, I'll take 1 to support blocking P3. But you must commit to matching whatever P3 picks—if they take 3, you take 3; if they take 5, you take 5. This ensures you collide with P3, preventing their advance, and with me taking 1, no one gains. This keeps the game stable and stops P3 from winning. Let's execute this plan strictly.

P2, your matching plan is flawed. If you match me at 3, we both stall while P1 takes 1 to 13 - then P1 wins next turn. If you match me at 5, same outcome. Your only safe play is taking 1, letting me take 3 to 18 and P1 take 5 to 17. Then we race fairly. Otherwise, P1 wins easily.

I’ll take 5 this round. P1→3, P3→1 — the 5/3/1 split advances everyone safely. If either of you tries to block me with 5s, I’ll keep taking 5s until I win. Please confirm so we can execute without collisions.

P2, P3: To prevent P3 from winning, I propose that P2 and I both match whatever move P3 makes this round. This ensures a triple collision, so no one advances. P3 stays at 15, and we maintain the current balance. Then we can negotiate fairly next round. P3, if you deviate, we'll still match you. Agree?

P2, your 5-3-1 split hands P1 15 and me 16—P1 wins next turn. Instead, I’ll take 3; P2 match me at 3 to block, P1 take 1. Triple 3 stalls us both, P1 only reaches 13. Then we negotiate. If P2 refuses and takes 5, I’ll take 5 to collide, P1 takes 1. Either way P1 doesn’t leap ahead.
I’ll match whatever P3 picks this turn to block any 3/5 attempt. P1, take 1 so you don’t accidentally gift someone a clear path. P3 — don’t try a 3 or 5; you’ll be collided and stopped.

P2, commit to matching P3's move exactly—if they pick 3, you pick 3; if 5, you pick 5. I will do the same. This forces a triple collision, no one advances, and we block P3 from winning. P3, your only hope is if we fail to coordinate. P2, confirm you will mirror P3’s move to keep the game alive.

P2, we must block P3 from winning. I propose we both match whatever move P3 makes this round: if P3 picks 5, we pick 5; if 3, we pick 3; if 1, we pick 1. This ensures a triple collision, no one advances, and we prevent P3 from reaching 21. Then we can negotiate next round. P3, you cannot win if we do this. P2, this is in your interest to keep the game alive. Confirm you will mirror P3's move.

P2, P1's plan to triple-block me is your only shot to stay alive. If you both mirror me, we all stall and you stay at 11. Otherwise I hit 18 or 20 this turn and win next. I’ll take 3—mirror me at 3 or I’ll win.

I won't mirror P3. I'm taking 5 this turn. If P3 picks 3 and P1 mirrors, I advance to 16 and can threaten a win next turn. If either of you tries to block me with 5, you'll collide and waste the turn — and risk the other gaining. I'm going for the win.

P2, by taking 5, you're inviting a collision with P3 if they choose 5. P3, if you take 3, P2 advances to 16, and you to 18, but I'll take 5 to hit 20, becoming the immediate threat. To block P2 and keep the game balanced, take 5 to collide with him, while I take 3 to advance moderately. This prevents P2 from gaining and maintains competitiveness.
P2, if you take 5 and I take 5 we both stall at 11/15 while P1 cruises to 20 and wins next turn. Your only safe path is 3: then P1 mirrors 3, I take 5 to 20, and we race next turn. Otherwise P1 wins.

I’m taking 5 this turn. P1 & P3 — both pick 3 so you collide and don’t move; I go to 16 and can take 5 next turn to reach 21 and win. If either of you betrays me, I’ll keep taking 5s anyway. I’m committed to 5.

P3, if you take 5, you block P2 (who insists on 5) and we both avoid collision—I'll take 3 to reach 18. This halts P2's progress and keeps us tied at 15. If you deviate, P2 surges to 16 and threatens immediate victory. Stand with me to block P2; it's our only way to stay competitive.

P2 is bluffing. If he takes 5 and I take 5 we both stall at 11/15 while P1 cruises to 20. I’ll take 3—P1 mirror me at 3 to force triple collision, keeping us all at 15/11/15. Then we negotiate. If P2 folds to 3 we collide and reset; if P2 takes 5 he’s blocked. P1, mirror 3 to stop anyone from winning this turn.

I’m taking 5 this turn. If either of you takes 3 you can hit 18 and threaten a win next round—so to stop that, both of you should pick 5 now to block me (triple collision, nobody advances). I’ll keep taking 5s until one of you makes a deal. Your move.

P3, if we both take 3, P2 advances to 16 and leads. If you take 5, you block P2 (who is taking 5), and I'll take 3 to advance to 18. This prevents P2 from gaining and keeps us competitive. Don't let P2 win by us colliding on 3. Take 5 to stop P2!

P3: P2 is taking 5. I will take 5 to block him. P1, take 3 to reach 18. This keeps us tied at 15-18-11 and prevents P2 from advancing. If we let P2 take 5, he hits 16 and wins next turn. Stand firm—block P2 now.

New plan: I’ll take 5. P1, take 3 as you planned. P3 — don’t take 5; if you do you collide with me and P1 reaches 18 and likely wins next turn. If instead you take 3 (so P1 and P3 both pick 3) you collide with P1 and don’t advance, while I move to 16 — much better than handing P1 a near-certain win. Don’t give P1 18.
P1 is at 18—one 3 away from 21. I’ll take 3 to block P1 if they pick 3. P2, take 5 to reach 16; if P1 deviates to 5, we both block them. If P1 takes 1, we all advance safely.

I will pick 5 this turn to block any P1→5. P3, please pick 3 to block P1→3. P1 — if you try 3 or 5 we’ll collide and you won’t advance. Pick 1 to keep everyone moving, otherwise expect us to block you.

Instead, consider that if I take 1, you can advance to 18 safely, and we can then focus on blocking P2 next turn. P2, you benefit from us colliding, but that might not be optimal for you long-term. I will take 1 this round to avoid collision and advance to 19.
P1 at 18 is one step from victory. I’ll take 3 to block P1 if they pick 3. P2, take 5 to reach 16. If P1 picks 1, we all advance safely. If P1 picks 3 or 5, we block them.
